name: Aniline, at plant
description: The aniline dataset represented in this module includes data for nitric acid and nitrobenzene to conceal the confidential data of a provider company.  Steam/heat is produced as a coproduct during this process. The energy amount for this coproduct is reported separately as recovered energy. This process has net water outputs. The mass imbalance is due to unavailability of the weight of water inputs to production and outputs to nature. Quantities may vary slightly between the reference to main source and and this module due to rounding.  Important note: although most of the data in the US LCI database has undergone some sort of review, the database as a whole has not yet undergone a formal validation process.  Please email comments to lci@nrel.gov.

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in the presence of a copper-chromium or copper-silica catalyst, or by vapor phase ammonolysis of phenol and ammonia
processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

flow.name: Natural gas, combusted in industrial boiler

exchanges.description: Values for barge transport are calculated based on average fuel consumption rates as reported in Transportation Energy Data Book: Edition 22 from Oak Ridge National Laboratory, September 2002: 22% of barges use diesel fuel in their engines, 78% use residual oil to generate steam for steam turbines, and a barge that consumes residual oil consumes 3.4 gallons per 1,000 ton-miles

exchanges.description: This emission was reported by fewer than three companies. To indicate known emissions while protecting the confidentiality of individual company responses, the emission is reported only by order of magnitude.

This emission was reported by fewer than three companies. To indicate known emissions while protecting the confidentiality of individual company responses, the emission is reported only by order of magnitude.

Waterborne emissions collected for nitrobenzene and aniline included those sent to deepwell disposal. Emissions sent to deepwell disposal are not included in the table as they are not released to a water source. The following emissions were reported as being sent to deepwell disposal: toluene, phenol, 2-DNP, aniline, and nitrobenzene. This emission was reported by fewer than three companies. To indicate known emissions while protecting the confidentiality of individual company responses, the emission is reported only by order of magnitude.
